author: _____josh_____
content:
Of course the fees issue is being recognised. The network is unusable with current fees.

I don't think forcefully pushing the gas limit is the solution. The network has a lot of spare capacity, there just isn't enough incentive for the miners to clear the backlog. 

All network capacity is being hijacked by NFTs. These people don't even care how much they pay in fees. They're happy to bid gas up to 4000 and still pay a priority fee on top of that. There's no competing with them as regular users. The financial incentive of flipping a NFT is just too great. You can't increase the gas limit faster than the NFTs can spam the network. At some point you will also hit the limit where it no longer compensates miners for uncle risk.

I think the base fee stepper is too sensitive at the moment. Panic bidding can send gas higher but there's not enough time for it to come back down.

author: gwintery
content:
I think your understanding is wrong
If by backlog you mean transactions not included that is below the basefee, then it does not affect the 'fee picker' at all. The next basefee (price) is simply a function of how full the previous block is from my understanding. So a full 30M block will raise it by 12.5% and vice versa.

author: gwintery
content: as a case study, when EIP 1559 started, basefee started at 1 gwei, and due to people willing to pay more than that, blocks continued to be full and base fee increases accordingly. Hence, clearing the backlog would not affect things at all.

author: _____josh_____
content:
OP is simply frustrated, like regular people who actually need to use the network, with how the average fee is now 3x of pre-1559.

Yes there might be more on chain activity since then but spikes faded much faster back then. Single digit gas was a thing for most times. Now the daily low is higher than the max of most days and eth is also 2x higher resulting in double pain to people trying to use the network. It's locking out anyone who isn't using it for NFTs and to be happy about the current status quo just shows which side of the market you're on (the price cheerleader who doesn't care about usability).

To be dismissing the detrimental effect to transactions on the chain is just sad.

author: sky.cactus
content: We have had times in pre -1559 history when fees were consistently much higher for very long periods of time.  You cannot compare two arbitrary points in time and assert that demand was the same between them.

author: sky.cactus
content: 1559 does make it easier to ex.ress willingness to pay, which does mean there is less opportunity to profit from exploiting market inefficiency.

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, there are some people who were previously able to capture sudden drops in demand by paying very close attention who now will struggle to find those opportunities because it is easier for people to now express their desires more clearly to the protocol.
